statement: Use the derivative of a function to determine intervals of increase and decrease.
Set the derivative equal to zero to find critical points.
Use the second derivative to classify critical points as maxima, minima, or points of inflection.
For absolute extrema on a closed interval, evaluate the function at critical points and endpoints.
Interpret f'(x) as the slope of the tangent line at x, to analyze graph behavior.
When solving optimization problems, express the quantity to optimize as a function of a single variable before differentiating.
Analyze the sign change of the derivative to determine where a function transitions from increasing to decreasing or vice versa.
For area under a curve, integrate the function over the specified interval.
To find average value of a function on [a, b], compute (1 / (b - a)) times the definite integral from a to b.
When a problem involves motion, interpret the derivative as velocity and the integral as total displacement.
If f(−x) = f(x) for all x in the domain, then f(x) is an even function.
If f(−x) = −f(x) for all x in the domain, then f(x) is an odd function.
The graph of an even function is symmetric about the y-axis.
The graph of an odd function is symmetric about the origin.
For definite integrals, if f(x) is even, then ∫ from −a to a of f(x) dx equals 2 times ∫ from 0 to a of f(x) dx.
For definite integrals, if f(x) is odd, then ∫ from −a to a of f(x) dx equals 0.
When analyzing symmetry, test whether f(−x) equals f(x) or −f(x) to determine if a function is even or odd.
Use function symmetry to simplify definite integrals over symmetric intervals.
Even functions multiplied together result in an even function. Odd functions multiplied together result in an even function. Multiplying an even and an odd function results in an odd function.
If a function exhibits neither even nor odd symmetry, treat it as a general function for integration and analysis.
The slope of the tangent line to the graph of y = f(x) at x = a is given by f'(a).
The equation of the tangent line to y = f(x) at x = a is y = f'(a)(x - a) + f(a).
If the slope of the tangent line is zero at x = a, then the point (a, f(a)) is a horizontal tangent point.
To find the point where a tangent line has a specified slope m, solve f'(x) = m.
When a tangent line is parallel to a given line, equate the derivative f'(x) to the slope of that line.
A function is differentiable at x = a only if it is continuous at x = a.
At a point where the left-hand derivative and right-hand derivative are not equal, the function is not differentiable.
Absolute value functions such as y = |x| are not differentiable at sharp corners or cusps.
For piecewise functions, check both continuity and matching derivative slopes at boundary points to determine differentiability.
If a function has a vertical tangent or infinite derivative at x = a, the function is not differentiable at that point.
When a function has domain restrictions or conditional expressions, divide the solution process based on the given conditions.
For absolute value functions, split the problem into cases based on the sign of the inner expression.
When solving piecewise functions, analyze each case separately and then combine results as appropriate.
Inequalities in the problem statement should trigger splitting the analysis into separate cases that respect those inequalities.
After solving separate cases, recombine the results carefully, considering overlapping or disjoint conditions.
To find local maximum or minimum values of a differentiable function, solve f'(x) = 0 and analyze critical points.
On a closed interval, evaluate the function at critical points and at endpoints to determine the absolute maximum and minimum.
When analyzing the range of a function, consider both the function's critical points and the behavior at the domain's endpoints.
In optimization problems, carefully apply constraints to limit the feasible region before finding extrema.
Use the behavior of the derivative (sign change) around critical points to confirm whether they correspond to maxima, minima, or neither.
To determine the range of a continuous function on a closed interval, evaluate critical points and endpoints.
For functions with square root, logarithm, or fractional forms, analyze domain restrictions first, then trace possible output values to determine the range.
For invertible functions, the range of the original function equals the domain of its inverse.
When analyzing the graph of a function, project the entire curve onto the y-axis to infer the range.
For composite functions, consider the output of the inner function as the domain for the outer function to trace the composite range.
The derivative of the position function s(t) with respect to time t gives the velocity function v(t).
The derivative of the velocity function v(t) gives the acceleration function a(t).
The definite integral of the velocity function over a time interval gives the total displacement during that interval.
To find total distance traveled, integrate the absolute value of the velocity function over the time interval.
To analyze when an object changes direction, solve for the points where the velocity function v(t) equals zero and check sign changes.
To compute a definite integral, first find the indefinite integral (antiderivative) of the integrand.
After finding the antiderivative, evaluate it at the upper and lower limits and subtract to get the definite integral result.
For piecewise functions or functions with sign changes, split the integral into separate intervals before calculating.
When integrating absolute value functions, express them as piecewise functions to correctly compute the integral.
Use symmetry properties of even or odd functions to simplify integrals over symmetric intervals when possible.
Recognize ∫(1/x) dx as a logarithmic integral, with the result ln|x| + C.
For integrals involving exponential functions like ∫(e^x) dx, apply the rule that the derivative and integral of e^x are both e^x.
If the integrand contains a composite function and its derivative, apply substitution method (u-substitution) to simplify the integral.
For integrands matching the form ax^n, apply the power rule of integration: ∫(x^n) dx = (x^{n+1})/(n+1) + C.
Identify trigonometric integrals (e.g., ∫sin(x) dx or ∫cos(x) dx) and apply basic trigonometric integration formulas.
If a function has the form f(g(x)), recognize it as a composite function and prepare to apply chain rule for differentiation.
When differentiating f(g(x)), apply the chain rule: f'(g(x)) × g'(x).
For integrals involving composite functions where the derivative of the inner function appears, apply substitution method (u-substitution) for simplification.
When solving problems involving the domain or range of a composite function, analyze the output of the inner function and its compatibility with the outer function.
For inverse function differentiation, use the relationship (f⁻¹)'(x) = 1 / f'(f⁻¹(x)), recognizing the inverse as a special case of composite function analysis.
For differentiable functions f(x), the derivative of |f(x)| is (f(x) / |f(x)|) * f'(x) whenever f(x) ≠ 0.
For composite functions g(x) = |f(u(x))|, the derivative is (f(u(x)) / |f(u(x))|) × f'(u(x)) × u'(x), wherever f(u(x)) ≠ 0.
If the derivative magnitude at a point equals a constant multiple of the function value at that point, express as |f'(a)| = k * |f(a)| and solve accordingly.
